comments:
I was using the openarchitectureware to create an ecore model as psdsl.ecore:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ASCII"?>
<ecore:EPackage xmi:version="2.0"
    xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns:ecore="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore" name="pfdsl"
    nsURI="http://uk.ac.open/pf" nsPrefix="pfdsl">
  <eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="ProblemDiagram">
    <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="name" eType="ecore:EDataType http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore#//EString"/>
  </eClassifiers>
</ecore:EPackage>

When I use the "dynamic object" generation in the "Self reflective ecore editor", a simple EMF model is saved as the following XMI. (Note I entered one attribute "name" in the ecore editor before I save it. Otherwise, the default one does not present the error described below.)

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="ASCII"?>
<pfdsl:ProblemDiagram xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:pfdsl="http://uk.ac.open/pf" name="example"/>

I can open this file in the XMI editor without problem.

Then I used the above Ecore metamodel to generate the editor plugins such that I could open the same XMI file into the generated EMF editor. However, the following exception is fired when the file is being loaded:

org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl$1$DiagnosticWrappedException: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.xmi.FeatureNotFoundException: Feature 'name' not found. (platform:/resource/Examples/pf/out.pfdsl, 2, 127)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.handleDemandLoadException(ResourceSetImpl.java:307)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.demandLoadHelper(ResourceSetImpl.java:268)
	at org.eclipse.emf.ecore.resource.impl.ResourceSetImpl.getResource(ResourceSetImpl.java:390)
	at pfdsl.presentation.PfdslEditor.createModel(PfdslEditor.java:906)
	at pfdsl.presentation.PfdslEditor.createPages(PfdslEditor.java:962)
	at org.eclipse.ui.part.MultiPageEditorPart.createPartControl(MultiPageEditorPart.java:276)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.EditorReference.createPartHelper(EditorReference.java:596)
	...

Another hint for the error is, when I try to open the XMI document through the API, it reports the following exception:

java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.emf.ecore.impl.EFactoryImpl
	at pfdsl.impl.PfdslFactoryImpl.init(PfdslFactoryImpl.java:34)
	at pfdsl.PfdslFactory.<clinit>(PfdslFactory.java:26)
	at pfdsl.impl.PfdslPackageImpl.<init>(PfdslPackageImpl.java:49)
	at pfdsl.impl.PfdslPackageImpl.init(PfdslPackageImpl.java:85)
	at pfdsl.PfdslPackage.<clinit>(PfdslPackage.java:59)
	at my.parse.save_model(parse.java:77)
	at my.parse.main(parse.java:38)

the problematic statement is the initialization for the PfdslPackage.eINSTANCE:

77 resourceSet.getPackageRegistry().put(
         PfdslPackage.eNS_URI, 
         PfdslPackage.eINSTANCE);

I am wondering whether the Ecore model generated from the openarchitectureware is incorrect, or the EMF code generation is incorrect.

I can't reproduce any problems using this model.  It happily reads and writes instances of this:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<pfdsl:ProblemDiagram xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:pfdsl="http://uk.ac.open/pf" name="fasdfasdf"/>

It sounds like you have more of an installation problem.  You need to track down what's going wrong with the intialization of the package and factory...

Confirmed, after I reinstalled everything and curiously the problem is gone !
Thank you for the help.
